abstract: The agreement ended a decade of legal strife that cost the world’s top maker of software 1.67 billion euros in fines and penalties and forced it to alter the way it did business in Europe.
snippet: The agreement ended a decade of legal strife that cost the world’s top maker of software 1.67 billion euros in fines and penalties and forced it to alter the way it did business in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN  European regulators dropped their antitrust case against Microsoft on Wednesday after the software maker agreed to offer consumers a choice of rival Web browsers. The move ended a decade of legal strife that cost the world's top maker of software 1.67 billion euros in fines and penalties and forced it to alter the way it did business in Europe.
